title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe a potential negative impact of the waste water released by the power plant on other aquatic species, such as any of the following:

  • Warming of the water near where the waste water/it is released reduces the amount of dissolved oxygen available for aquatic organisms to use/breathe

  • Warming of the water near where the waste water/it is released could impact the survival/health of species with a range of tolerance for the original/lower water temperatures

  • Warming of the water near where the waste water/it is released could alter/affect the timing of reproductive cycles for aquatic species

The response describes a potential negative impact of the waste water released by the power plant on other aquatic species, such as one of the following:

  • Warming of the water near where the waste water/it is released reduces the amount of dissolved oxygen available for aquatic organisms to use/breathe

  • Warming of the water near where the waste water/it is released could impact the survival/health of species with a range of tolerance for the original/lower water temperatures

  • Warming of the water near where the waste water/it is released could alter/affect the timing of reproductive cycles for aquatic species

title: Part D(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe a characteristic of the manatees that increases their vulnerability to the recent decline of seagrasses, such as any of the following:

  • They eat seagrass/are herbivores, so they would have less food/starve

  • They require a lot of energy to survive, so they would have less food/starve

  • They inhabit warm water, so they would need to travel to colder waters/further to find food/seagrass

  • They have a low reproductive/maturation rate, so they would take longer to recover from loss of food source

The response describes a characteristic of the manatees that increases their vulnerability to the recent decline of seagrasses, such as one of the following:

  • They eat seagrass/are herbivores, so they would have less food/starve

  • They require a lot of energy to survive, so they would have less food/starve

  • They inhabit warm water, so they would need to travel to colder waters/further to find food/seagrass

  • They have a low reproductive/maturation rate, so they would take longer to recover from loss of food source

title: Part D(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the change in energy flow through the trophic levels that occurs when there is a significant loss of seagrasses, such as any of the following:

  • Less energy will flow/is available to organisms in higher trophic levels

  • Less energy from the Sun is stored by producers

  • Less energy will flow/is available to organisms in higher trophic levels

  • Less energy from the Sun is stored by producers

title: Part E(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose a solution to reduce nutrient or sediment pollution in an estuary that is surrounded by urban development, such as any of the following:

  • Replace existing pavement with permeable pavement

  • Add vegetation where it will intercept runoff

  • Reduce fertilizer use in the area

  • Install barriers/Construct fences where they will intercept runoff

  • Improve wastewater treatment plants in the area

The response proposes a solution to reduce nutrient or sediment pollution in an estuary that is surrounded by urban development, such as one of the following:

  • Replace existing pavement with permeable pavement

  • Add vegetation where it will intercept runoff

  • Reduce fertilizer use in the area

  • Install barriers/Construct fences where they will intercept runoff

  • Improve wastewater treatment plants in the area

title: Part E(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not justify the solution proposed in part (e)(i) by providing an additional advantage of reduced nutrients in an estuary, other than one related to manatees, such as any of the following:

  • Reduces eutrophication

  • Increases biodiversity/species richness

  • Improves water clarity

  • Increases ecotourism

  • Reduces cost of water treatment

  • Increases profits for commercial fisherman

The response justifies the solution proposed in part (e)(i) by providing an additional advantage of reduced nutrients in an estuary, other than one related to manatees, such as one of the following:

  • Reduces eutrophication

  • Increases biodiversity/species richness

  • Improves water clarity

  • Increases ecotourism

  • Reduces cost of water treatment

  • Increases profits for commercial fisherman

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one ecological problem that results from exposure to photochemical smog, such as any of the following:

  • Causes respiratory problems/eye irritation in animals

  • Reduces photosynthesis

  • Slows/Inhibits/Stunts plant growth

  • Increases the susceptibility of plants to pests and disease

The response identifies one ecological problem that results from exposure to photochemical smog, such as one of the following:

  • Causes respiratory problems/eye irritation in animals

  • Reduces photosynthesis

  • Slows/Inhibits/Stunts plant growth

  • Increases the susceptibility of plants to pests and disease

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe a potential disadvantage of using hydrogen fuel cells to power automobiles, such as any of the following:

  • High cost to manufacture automobiles that use hydrogen fuel cells

  • Obtaining hydrogen requires a lot of energy/may consume more energy than the hydrogen fuel can produce

  • Hydrogen is explosive/flammable (may catch fire)

  • Lack of infrastructure (such as fueling stations) for hydrogen fuel

  • Obtaining hydrogen often uses fossil fuels

  • Hydrogen must be obtained by separating it from natural gas or water

The response describes a potential disadvantage of using hydrogen fuel cells to power automobiles, such as one of the following:

  • High cost to manufacture automobiles that use hydrogen fuel cells

  • Obtaining hydrogen requires a lot of energy/may consume more energy than the hydrogen fuel can produce

  • Hydrogen is explosive/flammable (may catch fire)

  • Lack of infrastructure (such as fueling stations) for hydrogen fuel

  • Obtaining hydrogen often uses fossil fuels

  • Hydrogen must be obtained by separating it from natural gas or water
